comments:
This occurred in I200402121600.  I tried switching perspectives, and it had no
effect.  The cursor was stuck as a busy cursor.  I had to shutdown Eclipse.  On
shutdown, it complained of an error.  This is what appeared in the log.  I'm not
sure whether the shutdown or the initial problem caused this stack trace to appear.

Both of these are in response to switching perspectives 
(SetPagePerspectiveAction.run).

ContentOutline.java:218 is:
protected void showPageRec(PageRec pageRec) {
-->	IPageSite pageSite = getPageSite(pageRec.page);

WorkbenchPage.java:2768 is in setPerpsective(IPerspectiveDescriptor):
	getClientComposite().setRedraw(true);

It's very strange that the page's composite has been disposed.  This should 
only happen when the window is closed, or possibly if all perspectives in the 
page are closed.  But neither is the case here since you're switching between 
perspectives.

WorkbenchPage.firePartActivated should protect itself from plugin failures 
using SafeRunnable.  Actually, it already does in the part listeners, but not 
in the selection service.  The case here is in the part listeners so it should 
have properly dealt with the exception and kept running.

Not sure how the ContentOutline's PageRec got a null page.
Was there anything in the log prior to these stack traces?
Do you remember what state the Outline view was in in both perspectives (fast 
view / regular view? showing content for which editor?)
Doug, I'm at a loss to explain this one.  Has is reoccurred recently?
No, I haven't seen this again.  My guess would be a a call to 
"PageBookView.partClosed" after the PageBookView has been disposed.  I'm not 
sure how this could happen though.  Perhaps the error is more symptomatic of 
some more catastrophic failure elsewhere (e.g., an exception occurring while 
processing an event which disposes of a page book view). 
Yes, it looks like a whole window got disposed but was not properly cleaned up.
Since we can't reverse engineer this, and it has not reoccurred, I'm going to
close as WORKSFORME.
